args: With the smoldering remains of my\nkingdom at my back, I made for the\nFaewood and Finlorda.
We had remained close since we met\nduring my travels with Aurelius as a youth.
I thought his vast knowledge of magics\nmight could breathe life back into Sheila.\nIt was a faint hope, but I clung to it tightly.
(It feels an eternity since I entrusted her\ninto Finlorda's care. Perhaps reviving the\ndead is impossible, even for him.)
Your daughter's procedure is complete,\nKing Gatov.
I thank you for the generous care you've\nshown. But tell me, is Sheila...?
You're alive! Oh, thank the heavens!
What's wrong, my dear child?\nWhy do you not respond?
King Finlorda's efforts succeeded in\ngranting life to your daughter anew.
But while her body may be restored,\nI fear her soul...
I stood wordless in my confusion until Finlorda\nat last explained.
He had used Sheila's blood to create an entirely\nnew body, then housed her soul within it.
But the procedure had left scars upon that soul.\nShe was now a hollow shell of a personâ€”\na shade of her former vibrant self.

Finlorda offered apology after apology, but he bore
no guilt in the matter. Surely this was heaven's
will, divine punishment for a king who abandoned
his people to save his own kin. And yet...
So long as you live, hope yet remains.\nThe two of us will go in search of a way\nto restore you.
I became a mercenary, traveling the land\nfrom battlefield to battlefield.
It both kept food on our table and allowed\nme to search for a way to cure Sheila.
At each new destination, I would seek out\nnew treatments for her soul. We attempted\nmore of them than I can even remember.

Not a one bore fruit, yet still I held to the
belief that I could make her whole once
more. Alas, perhaps that very hope was
the thing that blinded me...
These are her lodging fees up front.\nI plan to return in three months' time,\nbut paid for a half-year just in case.
I ask that you keep my daughter safe\nat your inn until the day I return.
Cor, but she's a strange one, isn't she?\nJust starin' off into space, she is.
She may not speak, but her wits are sound\nand she communicates enough to get by.\nI promise she will cause you no trouble.
Sheila. I must head back to the front lines.\nI ask your patience until I'm able to return.
It was among the fiercest wars I'd seen. Our side\nfaced terrible losses, and morale was nonexistent.\nYet still I fought, for I knew Sheila waited for me.
Blast! They hold the upper hand! Are there\nnone among you who can turn this fight?!
I've already kept my daughter waiting\noverlong, so I shall finish this apace.
Aaah ha ha! You broke their ranks, Gatov!\nI see now the legends of the Blazewolf\nwere no exaggeration!
Their flank lies exposed! Strike as one!
Your efforts saved my army, Gatov.\nYou have my heartfelt thanks.
I have done nothing to merit such praise.\nI simply earned my fee as a hired blade.

No need for such false humility! Now then,
our scouts have just located the enemy
stronghold, and I would have you lead
the strike against it.
I believe my contract in your service ends\nwith the battle here today, sirâ€”and as my\nchild waits for me, I fear I must decline.
But this enemy has tormented my country\nfor generations! Routing them now could\nfree us from that terror and bring us peace!
Please, Blazewolf! Lend us your strength,\nthat I might help my countrymen at long\nlast shed the yoke of oppression!
(It's been nearly three months, and I told\nthe innkeep I would return soonâ€”yet I DID\npay for half a year's rent...)
(Sheila should be safe and comfortable\nenough there for a while yet.)
Very well, sir. I shall remain in your\nservice a short while longer.
The day the war was won, I raced back to the inn\nwhere Sheila waited. Five months had passed\nsince I first left her there. But when I arrived...
Just that. Up and wandered off one day,\nquiet as the grave like always.
Yet I hear you rented her room to another.\nThe gold I gave you should have bought its\nuse for another month, at least.
Sorry, luv, but we run a business here.\nHad a vacancy, so I rented it out.
Do not think to brush me aside with such\nclaptrap, madam. Speak the truth!
That girl is all I have left in this world.\nIf I were to lose her, I...
Well, I cannot promise I would be able to\ncontrol myself in that instance.
Eeek! We was full up, so we was,\nand a guest came through promisin'\nwhat to pay double! I had no choice!
You cast Sheila out for a few extra coins?!
You'd been gone for months, so ya had!\nThought you was lyin' dead on some\nforeign battlefield!
And that child sure made no complaint!\nSo if anything happened to her once she\nleft, me hands are clean of it!
I'll not waste my breath debating it.\nWhere did she go after leaving the inn?
...Sheila! Where are you?!\nCall out if you can hear me!
(The innkeep said she headed for\nthese woods when she left...)
You seem unharmed. Oh, thank goodness.
(There are traces of a campfire...\nWas she waiting for me here?)
(Even without words, she surely could have\nmade her refusal plain to the innkeep or\nbegged the help of another.)
(But she didn'tâ€”or perhaps I'm wrong\nand she couldn't.)

Having lost her soul, Sheila had become numb to
any injustice perpetrated against her. Ever since
that incident, I came to regard her with a sense of
fragility I had not before.

I ceased my work as a mercenary in favor of
something that would afford me a stable
residence, for I could not bear to have her
out of my sight again.
